Merging Files with a Common Ancestor

Visual Merge allows you to combine the changes made to two text files based on the same revision of  the same file. It compares the two “new” file revisions with the revision checked out to create the working files.

If you need to merge binary files, you can use Visual Merge to make a three-way comparison, but you cannot edit the file within StarTeam. Instead, you must choose which of the two revisions of the file to use as the “merged” file.

To merge files during the check-in or check-out process:

  1. When you attempt to check in or check out a file with Merge status, the application displays a message stating that the file needs to be merged and asks if you want to merge it now. If you click No, the operation will stop. If you click Yes, Visual Merge will perform a three-way comparison.

    2. Note: If the files are binary, you may prefer to stop the operation, check out the most recent file from the application, and compare the two files in an appropriate editor. For example, you can compare two .doc files using Microsoft Word for Windows and make the necessary changes.

  2. What happens next depends on:

    • How the Visual Merge options are set for your workstation. For example, Visual Merge may be set to open all the time or only when actual conflicts exist between the two file revisions.

    • Whether the file is a text file or binary.

      • For text files, the Visual Merge window opens to allow you to view and edit the merged file it has created. Go to step 3.

      • For binary files, Visual Merge allows you to select either your working file or the tip revision by launching the Merged Results dialog. Go to step 4.

  3. If the Visual Merge window opens:

    1. Resolve all conflicts and make appropriate edits to the merged text file.

    2. Select File > Exit from the Visual Merge menu to return to the application. The application tells you whether you have resolved all conflicts and asks if you wish to save the file.

    3. Click Yes to replace your working file with the merged file. The file status will change from Merge to Modified. Go to step 5.

  4. If a Merged Results dialog opens, select Use source contents or Use target contents. Then click OK.

    • If you select Use source contents, the tip revision of this file is copied to your workstation. The file status will change from Merge to Current. Go to step 5.

    • If you select Use target contents, the status of the file changes from Merge to Modified because the file is considered to have merged. Go to step 5.

  5. The next step depends upon whether you are checking the file in or out.

    • If you are checking the file out, the operation ends. The merged file is now in your working folder, and you can modify it.

    • If you are checking the file in, a message box asks if you want to check in the merged file. Click Yes to perform this operation. The merged file then becomes the new tip revision, and the status of your working file changes to Current.
